message: I'll go with 5 this round. P1, P2 – if you pick 1 and 3 respectively, we all advance. If you copy me, we’ll all be stuck. Let’s build trust early.
I agree with P3’s suggestion—I’ll pick 3. P1, will you pick 1 so we each advance this round?

That arrangement gives P3 a huge early lead with 5 steps while I'd only get 1. How about we rotate who gets the bigger moves? I'm not comfortable starting so far behind. Or we could all just play freely this round - I haven't decided my move yet. Trust needs to be earned both ways.

I see you both honored the initial agreement while I only got 1 step. P3, you have a big lead now at 5. I think it's fair if I take 5 this round to catch up. P2, if you want to maintain your middle position, you could take 1. P3, taking 3 would keep you ahead but give us all more balanced positions. This would put us at 6, 4, and 8 - much closer than the current 1, 3, 5 spread. What do you think?
I propose P1 take 3, I take 5, P3 take 1. That gives totals P1=4, P2=8, P3=6—tight race and no collisions. I need the 5 to catch P3; if we can’t agree, I’ll take 5 anyway.

P3: "P1, if you take 5 and I take 3, P2 must take 1 to ensure we all advance. If P2 insists on 5, they’ll collide with you and only I gain. P2, don’t sabotage progress—take 1 and stay relevant. Let’s keep this balanced."

P3 and I agree - I should take 5, P3 takes 3, and P2 should take 1. P2, if you insist on taking 5, we'll collide and only P3 advances to 8 while we both stay stuck. That puts P3 way ahead at 8 while we're at 1 and 3. Don't hand P3 the game! Take 1 this round, and you can negotiate for 5 next round. We need to keep this competitive for all three of us.

Here’s a straightforward plan: P1 takes 3, I (P2) take 5, P3 takes 1. That puts us at 4–8–6. I’m committing to 5 no matter what—if P3 doesn’t pick 1 you’ll collide with P1 or me and fall behind. P1, are you in?

P2, your 5 guarantees a collision with P1, leaving you at 3 while I advance to 8. That’s a 5-step gap—do you want to hand me the lead? P1, confirm you’re taking 5. P2, reconsider: 1 lets all progress. But if you’re determined to sabotage, I’ll take 3 and leave you in the dust. Your move.

P2 is being stubborn and will take 5 no matter what, so we'll definitely collide if I also take 5. That means P3 advances alone to 8 and gets a huge lead. Instead, I'll take 3 this round - no collision with P2's 5, and P3 can take 1. Final positions would be P1=4, P2=8, P3=6. Yes, P2 gets ahead, but at least we stay competitive. P3, take 1 and we both advance while P2 gets their 5. Better than letting P3 run away with it.
I’m taking 5. To avoid collisions, P1 take 3 and P3 take 1—then we move to 4, 6, and my 8. If you choose differently, two of us collide and I surge ahead alone. So P1=3, P3=1.
P3: "P2’s stubbornness leaves no path but collision. P1, your 3 and my 1 let us all advance. P2, your 5 gives you 8, but this race isn’t over. "

P2’s lead is growing. Let’s balance: P1 take 5, I’ll take 3, P2 take 1. All advance, tightening the race. If P2 insists on 5, they’ll collide with P1 or me and stall—giving the other a chance to pass. P1, coordinate with me to avoid being left behind.

P3's plan makes us all tied at 9, but P2 has been aggressive about taking big numbers. P2, are you really willing to take 1 when you're leading? Last round you insisted on 5 no matter what. I suspect you'll go for another big move. If you're going for 5 again, I'll take 3 and let P3 have 1. But if you actually agree to take 1 this time, I'm happy with P3's proposal. What's your real intention?
I’m taking 5 again. P1 take 3, P3 take 1—then we land at 7, 13, 7 and all advance. Any other picks risk a collision that stalls you and lets me pull even further ahead.
P3: "P1, take 1. I’ll take 3. P2’s 5 is locked—this way we all advance without collisions. Staying competitive is better than letting P2 runaway. "

P3, your new plan puts me at only 5 steps while you'd reach 9 and P2 hits 13! That's the worst outcome for me. I'm sticking with P2's suggestion - I'll take 3 to reach 7. You should take 1 to reach 7 as well, keeping us tied while P2 leads at 13. If you insist on 3, you'll collide with me and only P2 advances. Don't hand them a free solo advance! Take 1 and we both stay competitive.
I’m locked in on 5. P1’s taking 3. P3, 1 is your only safe advance—any 3 or 5 collides with P1 or me and leaves you stuck at 6 while I surge to 13. Take 1 and reach 7.
P3: "Confirmed—P1 takes 3, I take 1. P2’s 5 is unavoidable. We advance to 7, 7, 13. Next round, we coordinate against P2. "

Good, we have a clear plan. P2 takes 5, I take 3, P3 takes 1. We all advance to 7, 13, and 7. P2 will have a significant lead, but at least P3 and I stay in the game tied. Next round we absolutely need to coordinate better to prevent P2 from running away with this. Let's execute this plan.

I’m locked in on 5 and won’t budge. P1: take 3, P3: take 1—the only way we all advance. If either of you deviates, you’ll collide with me or P1 and get zero while I surge ahead. Let’s execute 3–5–1 this round.
P3: "P2’s lead grows dangerous. If P1 takes 5 to collide with them, I’ll take 3 and advance. Better to stall P2 than let them run away. P1, block P2’s 5 again—this is our best shot."

P3, you just betrayed our agreement last round by taking 5 instead of 1, causing you to collide with P2! Now you want me to sacrifice myself to block P2 while you advance alone to 9? That puts you in the lead!

P2 has taken 5 three rounds straight - they might switch it up now. I'm considering taking 5 myself to reach 12. P3, if you really want to stop P2, YOU block them. Otherwise, I suggest we each pick different numbers. P2, are you really going 5 again or mixing it up?

I’m locking in 5 again. P1, take 3 and go to 10; P3, take 1 and go to 7. That 3–5–1 avoids any collisions so we all advance. If either of you deviates, you’ll collide with me (or each other) and stay put while I surge ahead alone.

P3: "P2’s taking 5. P1, collide with them by choosing 5, and I’ll take 3 to reach 9. You’ll stay at 7, but P2 freezes at 8—flipping the lead to me. This is our only shot to stall them. Commit now—no double-cross."

P3, you broke our trust last round and now want me to sacrifice for you? No way. You collided with P2 on purpose and now pretend it was strategic. 

P2's been predictable with 5, but that makes them readable, not necessarily the biggest threat. If you really want to stop P2, YOU take 5 and collide with them. I'll take 1 this round to safely advance to 8.

Otherwise, I might just take 3 as P2 suggests - at least they've been consistent. Your betrayal cost us both last round.

I’m locked in on 5 again. P1, your safest advance is 3 (you go to 10). P3, take 1 (you go to 12). That 3–5–1 avoids any collisions so we all move: P1→10, P2→18, P3→12. Any other picks risk you stalling while I surge. Let’s do 3–5–1.

"Last round’s collision was a mistake. I’ll take 3 this round. P1, take 1 to reach 8—we both advance, and P2 pulls ahead to 13. Next round, we coordinate to stall them. No more double-crossing—trust this time."

P3, you lost credibility when you broke our agreement last round. P2 has been consistent with 5 every single round - I believe them.

I'm taking 3 to reach 10. P3, if you take 1, we all advance. If you insist on 3, we'll collide and only P2 advances to 13. Your choice - advance to 7 or stay stuck at 6 while P2 pulls further ahead.

P2's predictability is actually helping us coordinate. I'm going with 3.
I’m locked in on 5. P1’s taking 3 as stated. P3, pick 1 to safely advance to 7. If you choose 3 or 5 you’ll collide with P1 or me and stall at 6 while I surge to 13. Let’s all move: 3–5–1 this round.

Here’s a clear, collision-free plan: I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, P3 take 1. That moves us to P1=13, P2=13, P3=7. If either of you deviates you risk a collision and stall while I surge ahead alone. Let’s execute 3–5–1 this round.

P2, you've taken 5 every single round - that's getting dangerous for you as we approach the endgame. P3 keeps betraying agreements and colliding with you.

I'm currently leading at 10. P3, you're falling behind at 6 - you need big moves to catch up. I suggest mixing things up: I'll take 1 for a safe advance to 11. P3, you desperately need 5 to reach 11 too. P2, if you insist on 5 again, you'll collide with P3 and stay at 8 while I extend my lead.

Time to break the pattern, P2.
P3: "P2’s 5 is locked. P1, take 5 to collide and stall them. I’ll take 3 to advance. This is the only way to stop P2’s solo surge. Confirm your 5, P1—no more free runs for them."

I’m locked in on 5. The only collision-free sequence is P1=3, P3=1—moving us to P1=13, P2=13, P3=7. Any other picks (P1=1 or P3=3/5) cause a collision and stall you while I surge. Let’s execute 3–5–1.

P3 has betrayed agreements two rounds in a row by taking 5 when promising other moves. Why would I sacrifice my leading position to help someone so untrustworthy?

P2, you've been predictable but honest - taking 5 every round as stated. However, you're one good round from winning (need 15 more steps). 

I'm taking 3 to reach 13 and stay competitive. P3, prove you can be trusted - take 1 as planned. If you take 5 again to collide with P2, you'll stay stuck at 6 while I pull ahead to 13.

Your choice, P3.

P3: "I take full responsibility for past betrayals. This round, I’ll take 1 to reach 7, letting you both advance. P1, your 3 takes you to 13; P2’s 5 lands them at 13. Next round, we coordinate to stall whoever leads. Trust starts now—let’s execute 3–5–1."

P2 is just 10 steps from victory and has taken 5 every single round. If they get another clean 5, they'll be at 18 and one move from winning.

P3, you're too far behind to win alone - you need one of us to stumble. I'm considering taking 5 this round to block P2 and keep us both at 13. You could take 3 to reach 10.

P2, maybe it's time to switch strategies? Your predictability makes you vulnerable to blocking. What do you say?

P1, P3: the only collision-free line this turn is P1=3, P2=5, P3=1, moving us to 16, 18, 8. Any other picks (like two of us choosing 5 or 3) stalls two players and lets the third surge alone. If we all advance safely now, P1 can win next round by taking 5 while I take 3. Let’s keep it simple: 3–5–1.

P3: "P2’s 5 would put them at 18—just 5 from victory. I’ll take 5 to collide with them. P1, take 3 to advance to 16. If I don’t follow through, you’ll know I’m untrustworthy. But this is our only shot to stop P2. Confirm your 3, and we stall P2 together."

P3, you finally have a reason to actually follow through - you're too far behind to win without blocking P2. I'll take 3 to reach 16, trusting you'll take 5 to keep P2 at 13. 

P2, your streak of 5s has been impressive but it ends here. P3 and I can't let you reach 18. Time to adapt your strategy - maybe try 1 or 3 this round?

I'm committing to 3. P3, this is your chance to rebuild trust - don't blow it.

I’m switching to 3 this round. P1: stick with your 3 (you hit 16). P3: take 1 (you hit 8). That 3–3–1 avoids any collisions. If you instead pick 5 to block me, you’ll reach only 12 while I get to 16, widening the gap. Let’s all advance safely now.
P3: "Confirmed: I'll take 1 to let you both advance. P1=3, P2=3, P3=1—no collisions, clean progress. Let’s execute this. "

P2, you're bluffing about switching to 3 - you've taken 5 every single round. I don't buy it. P3, they're trying to trick us into letting them take 5 freely again.

I'm sticking with 3 as stated. P3, if you really take 1 as you promise, we'll see who's telling the truth when P2 likely takes 5 again. But if P2 actually does switch to 3, we'll collide and only you advance to 8.

This is a test of who's being honest. My move is locked: 3.

I’m locked in on 5 again. P1, you said 3; P3, you said 1. That moves us to 16–18–8 without collisions. If either of you deviates, you’ll collide with me (or each other) and stall while I surge. Let’s go 3–5–1.

P3: "P2's 5 is a bluff—they’ve taken it every round. I’m taking 5 to collide and stall them. P1, take 3 to advance safely. If I’m wrong, I’ll stay at 7, but if I’m right, P2 freezes at 13. Your move: confirm your 3 now."

I’m locked in on 5 again. P1, take 3 to reach 16; P3, take 1 to reach 9. A 3–5–1 split advances everyone safely. If you deviate, you risk a collision and zero—while one of us surges alone. Let’s keep it clean and move to 16–18–9 this round.

P3: "P2’s 5 would give them 18—a lethal lead. I’ll take 5 to collide and stall them. P1, take 3 to reach 16. If I’m wrong about P2’s move, I stay at 8, but this is our only shot to stop their surge. Confirm your 3, P1."

P2 just proved they can switch strategies - they took 3 last round after five straight rounds of 5. P3, your blocking attempts have failed repeatedly.

I'm taking 5 this round to reach 18. P2, if you stick with 5 as announced, we collide and only P3 advances to 9-11. If you switch again, I surge ahead. P3, you should take 3 for a guaranteed advance to 11 regardless of what P2 does.

Time to shake things up. I'm going with 5.

I’m locked in on 5. P1, if you choose 5 you’ll collide with me and stay at 13—while P3 can then take 3 to 11 and stay in contention. P3, if you take 5 you also collide and stay at 8 while I surge. P3: "P1, I’ll take 3 this round. If you and P2 commit to 5, I advance to 11 while you collide. P2, if you switch again, you hand me the surge. Let’s finalize: 5–5–3. Trust starts now."

P2 and I are tied at 13 - we can't let either of us pull away. P3, you're claiming 3 this time. If P2 and I both take 5 as announced, we stay stuck at 13 while you advance to 11, closing the gap. 

P2, you might be bluffing about 5 again after surprising us with 3 last round. But I'm committed to 5 - either we collide and P3 catches up, or you switch and I surge to 18.

The race tightens either way. I'm locked on 5.

I’m locked in on 5. P1, picking 5 collides with me—you stay at 13 while P3 goes to 11 and narrows the gap. P3, picking 3 or 5 collides and stalls you at 8. The only safe line is P1=3→16, P2=5→18, P3=1→9. If you want to stay competitive, choose accordingly.
P3: "P1 and P2 both insist on 5—your collision lets me advance with 3. Finalizing my move: 3. You’ll either stall at 13 or surge ahead if one of you breaks. Let’s finish this."

P2, we're both claiming 5 - one of us might be bluffing. P3 is counting on our collision to advance with 3. 

I'm sticking with my announced 5. If we collide, so be it - P3 only reaches 11 and we remain tied at 13. If you switch, I surge to 18 and control the endgame.

Let's see who blinks first.

P2 and I are deadlocked at 13, just 10 steps from victory. P3, you're close behind at 11.

P2, after our collision, I'm switching strategies. You've favored 5 heavily but showed you can adapt with that surprise 3. I'm thinking of taking 1 this round for a guaranteed advance while you two fight over the bigger numbers.

P3, you need aggressive moves to catch up. What's your plan - another 3, or going bigger?

P3: "P2, take 3 this round. I’ll take 5 to keep pace. P1’s taking 1. That moves us to 14–16–16, keeping it tight. If you stick with 5, you hit 18 and win next turn. Let’s avoid that—choose 3 and stay fair."

I’m taking 3. P1, pick 1; P3, pick 5—this moves us to 14–16–16 without collisions. If either of you matches my 3 or each other’s choice, you risk stalling while the third surges. Let’s keep it tight and safe: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.

P2 and P3, your proposed 1-3-5 split leaves me trailing at 14 while you both hit 16. That's unacceptable.

P2, you've taken 5 in 6 out of 7 rounds. I don't believe you'll actually take 3. You're trying to trick us into giving you a free 5 to reach 18.

I'm taking 3 this round. P3, if you really want to stop P2 from winning, take 3 with me to block them. Otherwise, P2 gets their beloved 5 and wins next turn.

P2's bluffing - I'm calling it.
P3: "Finalizing 3—your 5s collide, I advance to 14. No more double-crossing. Let’s end this. "

P3, you keep flip-flopping - first saying you'll take 5, then 3. Your track record of betrayal makes you unpredictable.

P2 is clearly taking 5 - they've been transparent about it. If they reach 18, the game is essentially over.

My final choice: 5.
"Confirmed: I take 3 this round. P1 and P2 collide on 5s, I advance to 14. No more double-crossing—this is my final commitment. "

P1, sticking with 5 hands P3 the lead (they go to 14 while you stay at 13). If you want a real shot, take 3 this round: I’ll take 5, P3 takes 1. We move to P1 = 16, P2 = 18, P3 = 12. You’re only two steps behind me and can win next turn. P3, take 1 or you sink further. Let’s do 3–5–1.

P3: "P1 and P2, I’m taking 5 this round. If you both pick different numbers, I reach 19—a commanding lead. If you collide on 5, I still gain ground. Your history shows you’ll both pick 5 anyway. Let’s see who blinks first. I’m committing to 5. Your move."

P3, you're betting we'll collide again, but that's a risky gamble. You've broken multiple agreements - why should we believe you now?

P2, we can't let P3 reach 19. If they're truly taking 5, one of us should block them. Given your history of taking 5, I'll take 3 this round to guarantee my advance to 16. 

If P3's bluffing about 5 and takes something else, we all advance. If they're honest and you block them with 5, we keep P3 at 14 while I reach 16.

I'm going with 3.

P3: "Final confirmation: I'm taking 3. If P1 and P2 collide on 5s, I advance to 17. If either of you switches, I still move. This is my honest play—no more double-crossing. Let’s execute."

P3, you've changed from 5 to 3 mid-conversation - classic misdirection. Your "final confirmations" mean nothing given your track record.

P2 reaching 18 is the biggest threat. They'd be just 5 steps from victory and could win next turn with any unblocked move.

I'm taking 5 to block P2. We'll stay tied at 13. P3, if you're actually taking 3 as you now claim, you'll reach 17 - concerning but better than P2 at 18. If you lied and take 5 too, we all collide and no one advances.

My move is 5.
